div.p:
The historians work from the outer to the inner; from the
house they infer the tenant (teant) of the house. It is the house they (thy)
dwell upon; the chairs and the furniture of the house.
It is as if we were told bidden (nbideen) to infer from
a tweed suit, and six hats, and a fox terrier, and a
walking (waljing) stick and a c kitchen with a coal (col) fire and a
servant pcalled perhaps Joan the life and works (woks) of a novelist call that wrote the
and Save for and
and the voice of Anon singing at the back door the English
might be a dumb race, who suffered and (nad) ennjoyed in silence (silnce);
a race of merchants (me rhcnats), soldiers and priests (preists) builders who left behind them (thm)
stone houses, cultivated fields and vast cathedrals. but
not no words. The great house is silent; Only the furniture
remains (mains), stiff and ornate, fantastic (fanastic) and uncushioned.

At for instance sat at her table
writing letters. But Her letters to are letter written [illeg.]
from the pulpit; as intricate involved and formal as state
papers or legal documents or dying depositions (dyin depositons). She admonishes and preaches;
she expresses the violence of her temper and theher violence (violene) and her suspicions (suspiions);
suspicions of her soul. She is a counsellor admonishing a
subordinate. She is aware expressive only of the (th) wickedness of
men, the dangers and deceits of the world; and the
awfulness (awfu;ness) of her God. Greek and Latin come to her pen
as easily as English. If she has to descend (decend) to the actual object (objec)
a basket of strawberries (starwberries)-- it is with circumlocution (coircomlocution) and
dark threats. "I have sent them by the (th) boy of my kitchen,
a shrewd witted boy and prettily cachetized, but yet an
untoward crafty boy..." She writes only (onlt) to

exhort "God keep us sound in the faith and send us health
and a care to please God above all" Or to admonish---
"Be not speedy of speech, nor talk suddenly, but where
discretion requireth, and that soberly then....
Let not Lawson, that fox, be acquainted (acqaunited) with my letters..."
Fear of man, fear of God surround them as h as with the walls of (wallsof)
a dungeon. There is no gaiety, no freedom, no familiarity (familairity)
in (ni) the house (hose) she lives in. The sound of the Bible is in her
words (wars). Her prose takes its solemn (slolemn) strain. And the prose
of the bible will not adapt itself to the easy (eaxy), the colloquial (co oqu)
It is a garment to be put on when the mind is erect and
dignified, on state occasions (oaccions).

It is because they use of the prose of the bible when
they write prose that the Elizabethans are unknown to us.
It They can say nothing simple (simle), nothing intimate.
They are never (nevr) subtle; they are never shaded. Bright contrasted (contrastd)
colours meet on their faces. Carnation and snow (sanow);
ebony and gold. When we look at them we see them
in their farthingales (farthibgales) and ruffs (ru ffs);
young men's (men s) bodies
are stiffly sewn into doublets (dohblets) and school boys faces
are raised above starched collars; young (yong) women serve only to s
display heavy quilted dresses (dresse) stuck about with huge pearls.
The writer, towards (to rds) the end of the sixteenth century (sicteenth cnyury),
was separate from his audience (arudience); but he was still closely
connected with it. He was himself unspecialised, undifferentiated (un ifferent)
ated. His eye was stimulated by the crimsons and gold and
greens of the clothing. His ear was stimulated by the
sound of words For each ( ac ) word was given substance and sharpness

by the speaking voice. And the lutes (l tes) and the citherns (cithersn)
gave (have) lilt and rhythm (rhym) and melody to the spoken word.
His mind was full of half sung half spoken (spoekn) words;
full of undifferentiated words; old (ol) words, new words; French words
Latin words. No grammar bound them tightly together.
They were elastic. They could stretch to any length (lgneth). They could (cd)
could reflect (refelct) many colours; they could follow (fol ow) many tunes,
they could be danced to, and sung to. But they could not
follow the words of the speaking voice. For a moment then
there is a pause on the threshold of the great (gre t) Elizabethan (lizabethan)
room. The artist is not wholly writer, wholly musician, or
wholly painter (paineter). xmxsxmxsmssxmxsxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxsxmxmxmxmxmxmmx
xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxm. may be
; Spenser (Soenser) may be . It seems possible that the
great English art may not be the art of poetry.

The writer then came to birth with difficulty in
England; for so long as familiar letters are written in
Biblical prose there are limits to his freedom; a barrier
between the sayable and the unsayable. He is in being;
for the printing press has given him a name; but still
unspecialised, undifferentiated. The artist is not wholly
writer (write), wholly musician, or wholly painter. It seems
possible that the great English art may not be the art of
words. His eye is stimulated by the colour of the
of the clothing (clotning), of the pageantry. his ear by the sound of
words spoken aloud. For books were read aloud. " Pritchard (Prtitachrd)" wrote
"read aloud the ..... They read aloud
and the Faery Queen." Every word was given sharpness and
substance by the speaking voice. And the lute, the cithern,
the old full bodied instrument that still stands on a
chest (ches), gave (hgave) lilt, rhythm, melody to the word.
"Hardly one lighter or boat in three (hree) that had the goods
of a house in it , but there was a pair of virginals in
it" observed in 1666 when the people of London were
loading their goods onto boats to escape from the fire of
London. His mind the was full of undifferentiated words, old (ole)
words and new words; French and Latin. No grammar bound them
tightly together. They were elastic; they could be danced to
and sung to. But they could not follow the pace of the
speaking (spea ing) voice.

then in the is like a
half articulate monster rising from the depths of silence (silnce)
hung with the weeds and pearls of the deep sea in

he the writer has been so long submerged. We cannot read
the ; nor leave it unread (undread). It is a poem
without a plot; the metre, casting its regular fling of
sound, comes to ground too (to) evenly, too solidly, unlike
who goes on, simply, directly, at an even pace.
Great groups, composed, arranged, come together with the
forest (orest) for background (back rg und). must have seen Italian
pictures; or was it natural then to make compositions even
in words? The knights (Knihgyts) the ladies (ldaies) and the ogres
pass away amble their way through the glades and become
one with the clouds. Like a [cloud?] (lcliund) the words move up and
down; first (furst) lulling the ear then cloying the ear.
It has the sweetness of a dream; something cut adrift from
the rough Irish (rish) land which lay outside; it has freshness,
it has sharpness (csharpness). It is the thing itself;
it is the original design, from which and
made (mad) their copies.

Latimer heard them. He raged.
His is the voice of the new
